options.label: A
options.text: S3: Rapid atrial filling during early in ventricular systole

options.label: B
options.text: S4: vigorous atrial contraction late in diastole is required to augment filling of a hypertrophied, non-compliant ventricle

options.label: C
options.text: S1: Mitral and tricuspid valve closure

options.label: D
options.text: S2: Aortic and pulmonary valve closure

questions.correct_answer: A. S3: Rapid atrial filling during early in ventricular systole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S3: Rapid atrial filling during early in ventricular systole The third heart sound (S3) occurs during the rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole.

Highyeild:

S1 corresponds to mitral and tricuspid valve closure at the onset of systole S2 corresponds to aortic and pulmonary valve closure following ventricular ejection. S3-occurs during the rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole. S4 is sometimes physiological. More commonly, however, it is pathological, and occurs when it is required to augment filling of a hypertrophied, non-compliant ventricle (e.g. hypertension, aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). vigorous atrial contraction late in diastole

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: S4 is sometimes physiological. More commonly, however, it is pathological, and occurs when vigorous atrial contraction late in diastole is required to augment filling of a hypertrophied, non-compliant ventricle (e.g. hypertension, aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). Option: C: S1 corresponds to mitral and tricuspid valve closure at the onset of systole Option: D: S2 corresponds to aortic and pulmonary valve closure following ventricular ejection.

questions.text: All of the following are true about S1, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Cause by closure of mitral valve

options.label: C
options.text: Heard at the end of ventricular systole

options.label: D
options.text: Better heard with diaphragm of stethoscope

questions.correct_answer: C. Heard at the end of ventricular systole
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heard at the end of ventricular systole S 1 – It is produced primarily by closure of AV valve at the beginning of ventricular systole.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A -S1 is of Lower frequency than S2 Option B -S1 is caused by closure of mitral and tricuspid valves. Option D - S1 is better heard with diaphragm of stethoscope

questions.text: A 48 year old female, known case of RHD presented with a history of dyspnoea on exertion-NYHA grade 2-3. On examination she was found to have a tapping apex, loud S1 and an MDM in the apex with presystolic accentuation. Loud S1 in this condition is caused by:
questions.correct_answer: A. Prolonged flow through mitral valve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolonged flow through mitral valve Due to increased LA pressure and persistent LA-LV gradient even in late diastole, the mitral valve leaflets are open deep in the LV cavity when, normally, they would have been closed immediately following atrial contraction. The increased distance the cusps must travel during their closing motion contributes to loud S1)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - The intensity of the first heart sound (S1) is decreased in patients with first-degree AV block. Patients with first-degree AV block may have a short, soft, blowing, diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. Option C and D - calcification and immobilization of valve will cause decrease in intensity of S1

questions.text: A 38 year old female, known for rheumatic MS, presents with increasing dyspnea on exertion over the last 3 months. On examination, JVP is raised, and CXR shows a bag of water shaped cardiac silhouettes. On auscultation, S1 will be:

options.label: D
options.text: Heard just after upstroke of carotid pulse

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muffled Normally in a case of MS, S1 is loud. However in this patient, there are signs of right heart failure (raised JVP) associated with pericardial effusion (bag of water silhouette). Therefore in this case due to mechanical factor (increased distance between heart and stethoscope as a result of pericardial effusion) and pump failure, S1 will be muffled.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A ; Normally in a case of MS, S1 is loud . Option C : S1 is best heard over mitral area, and tricuspid area, not carotid Option D : S1 is heard just before the upstroke of the carotid pulse, not after.

questions.text: A 32year old male has an ECG done as a part of routine workup shows M pattern in V1, 2 and W pattern of QRS in v5, 6. On auscultation S1 will be:
questions.correct_answer: B. Split which increases with inspiration
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Split which increases with inspiration This patient has a right bundle branch block, which is evident from the M and W patterns in respective leads in ECG. Splitting of S1 can be due to delay in closure of tricuspid valve (as seen in right bundle branch block) or early opening of mitral valve. During inspiration venous return to RA increases and RA requires longer time to empty, further delaying closure of tricuspid valve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : S1 may not be heard in severe heart failure, massive pericardial effusion, etc, not in RBBB. Option C : The split will actually decrease on expiration because of reduced filling of RA. Option D : Reverse splitting of s2 is seen in aortic stenosis, LBBB.

questions.text: The first heart sound (S1) represents closure of the atrioventricular (mitral and tricuspid) valves as the ventricular pressures exceed atrial pressures at the beginning of systole. Loud S1 in mitral stenosis is caused by
questions.correct_answer: A. Prolonged flow through mitral valve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolonged flow through mitral valve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - S1 is louder if AV flow is prolonged because of mitral stenosis. Option B - prolonged PR interval (1st degree heart block)- mitral leaflets at a lesser distance than normal ➡ soft S1 Option C and D - Immobile mitral leaflet and with calcification in mitral stenosis (long standing MS)-soft S1 Reduced mobility of the valve (immobility , calcification ) and prolonged PR interval (1st degree heart block) are all causes of soft S1.

questions.text: The first heart sound (S1) represents closure of the atrioventricular (mitral and tricuspid) valves as the ventricular pressures exceed atrial pressures at the beginning of systole. Reverse splitting of first heart sound is heard in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both B and C First heart sound and splitting First heart sound (M1 T1) is produced by closure of mitral valve M1 and closure of tricuspid valve T1. The mitral valve closes slightly before the Tricuspid valve (M1 ➡T1) This normal splitting cannot be detected by auscultation because both components are low pitched and separated only by 20-30ms. Therefore splitting of first heart sound, wherever audible is considered pathological.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A -In Right bundle branch block normal splitting is seen.
